Patient: Anyway so I understand I have one point four from point four? Doctor: Yes. So the PSA is going up and the scans are showing slight worsening. Patient: I thought you said the scans didn’t… Family Member: That’s what you said last month. Healthcare Professional: Last time they had the prelim report, but… Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: So one of the areas and again like I said I don’t know what to make of this because it is on the bone scan. I thought I – did we talk about this? Okay. Family Member: Last time you said they were absolutely the same. One hundred perc- (nervous laugh)

text: Patient: I got to talk to the heart doctor now because he has me on the aspirin and the… Family Member: Unless you think… Patient: The tush doctor told me no aspirin. Doctor: Don’t take it until – but that could probably be temporary as long as the bleeding has stopped you know if a few weeks they may be able to go ahead and restart. Family Member: So would we be completely transferring care downtown then? Doctor: For? Family Member: Every visit. Doctor: For some time yes. Family Member: And this would be like at first I know it’s super intensive with tests, but then does it go to once a month or is it always more intensive? Doctor: It does eventually. Yes. text: Family Member: So it’s a monthly, a monthly thing? Doctor: So the treatment you actually take every single day, so, the pills, so what you what you do usually is that you come in, we make sure that you're taking you after usually fill out a drug diary so that we see how many like if you're missing days, you take the pills, and then we would give you refills of the pills. Family Member: Okay, so will there be a blood test when he comes back also? Doctor: Yeah. Not every single time. Family Member: oh OKAY. And how long is this trial for? Doctor: This one, I think it's for two years so that you can, you can stay on it. You can stay on it for two years. Usually, if people are getting benefit, and they're still on it, then usually we can work with the company to continue it. Even though technically the study ends. But that's not always the case. Technically. I mean, usually, that's not always the case. Family Member: But the study itself is for two years. Doctor: Yes, yes. Yes, yes. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: All right. So let me, um yeah, so this is the so this is the part that's part of the research that's going to be free of charge. So right now what we'll do is the blood for this is the specific gene that we're looking for. And then if you join the study, and you have the right genotype, we'll get all of these and then these other things are not part of their like part of standard treatment. So those don't get paid for by the study they get paid for by your insurance company as normal. Patient: By insurance. Doctor: So if you are okay with this, I will get your signature there and then. You have to put the time. Time is 450

text: Family Member: Oh okay. Doctor: You know smaller volume, here, three to six ounces rather than eight/ten. Family Member: Okay, okay. Is it, did it matter if he’s gluten free not? text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: If there’s a lot there, so things look really dark, it looks like it’s taken up like crazy, then you’re a good candidate for that treatment. If it’s so-so, I don’t know what their line is, but they kind of look at it, and if it doesn’t look like the cancer is really taken off, I don’t think you’re a candidate. I would say that most people are in the first group that the cancer makes a lot of this uh so uh one of the things we’re doing here is uh looking at the scan part. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So we’ve been looking at the imaging part to see how useful this is as an imaging agent but it’s also useful because if we do it here, and you’re very positive, it might suggest yes we should pursue this. Patient: Okay. Is it something than can tell you how extensive the cancer? Doctor: Yes. So the second part of that, it’s a good question. Just to, and because it’s very sensitive, it’s possible you do the scan, and they, say, oh, B__, your set of these, so many things you see here, there’s a lot more. Because they can see uh, what we’re limited by right now is as I told you these lymph nodes are enlarged. That’s pretty much all the radiologist can say right now. So if you have a normal lymph node it could be totally full of cancer. They won’t call it. They only call the ones that are bigger than normal. Patient: I see. Doctor: That’s the criteria. Patient: I see. Doctor: So this PSMA scan picks up those normal things that are too small. So often patients will get upstaged in a way where you thought you had five things and told that you have ten. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So you’ve got to be prepared for that kind of news that there’s more there.

text: Family Member 1: Oh okay. Doctor: See that's hard because any alcohol based products for our mouths are bad. Family Member 1: There’s alcohol, I forgot. Doctor: So it's a challenge for cancer patients. So like if you look at Listerine or Crest they have now the non alcohol version. So you could try that. Family Member 1: He likes to gargle with Listerine. Doctor: Yeah, there's a non alcohol version of Listerine. Patient: There is? Doctor: There is. Yeah, yeah, there's one I think that's purple and I'm pretty sure there's a blue one. Again, I peruse the poop in the mouth aisle, because I don't like to recommend things that you can't get access to. You know, when it sounds good on paper and in the textbooks, and then you go to Meijer, you go to Rite Aid and you're like, “what are you talking about, I've never seen it”. So I will peruse the same store as you guys shop at because if I don't see it then how are you going to play it? So I do know Crest has one that says no alcohol that's a blue and I'm pretty sure Listerine is purple that's a no alcohol, so those are two really good ones. You know I’d still cut it a little bit with the water. Family Member 1: What about toothpaste? Doctor: Same with a lot of the whitening and all that is very harsh on the gums. You know there's Sensodyne, which is very calming. Family Member 1: I have to do a prescription because Doctor: Oh, okay.

text: Patient: Right, right. Doctor: So you uh, we went through uh the you know clinical trial and you went to surgery, and uh when they did the surgery uh you had some lymph nodes uh that popped up, and we uh wanted to get a better sense of using the special PSMA scan, uh what was going on, where there was cancer left. And so we had to do the scan, and uh the good news is we found prostate cancer. Patient: Right. Doctor: Uh, and uh the bad news is we found prostate cancer, but we sort of knew it was there. Patient: Right. Doctor: And and what we saw on the scan basically is in your pelvis here, from here down to where the prostate was there’s still a lot of lymph nodes with prostate cancer in them. The good news is we didn’t see any higher; so it sort of ends at the pelvis, and we didn’t see any in the bones. Patient: That is good news. Doctor: So. So from my standpoint that’s really great news. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Um, because we knew there was cancer, and so now we know sort of about where it is. So the question is, is how do we proceed – Patient: Yes. Doctor: - uh to try and get rid of this. Um, and uh you know uh I certainly have no it’s easy for me to say; I have no regrets that you did that clinical trial.

text: Family Member: So how are you feeling about how he is doing? Patient: Disappointed. Doctor: …this is a slight set back that Xtandi didn’t last us as long as I had hoped it would. And honestly I don’t know if that is part of the sort of resistance of BRC - BRCA mutant disease or not. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: Nobody does really at this point because very few people have been really treated with Xtandi up front like that. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: So I think that is something to track down obviously, but um we’ll have to see how it goes. I’m just hoping you know we definitely have the Lynparza sort of as a fall back. Um again- Patient: So I’d be two steps away from chemo. Doctor: But getting that as well not quite and who knows how many more steps we’ll find as we go along, you know. Like I said this BET inhibitor wasn’t there what six months ago if you had needed this option and it wasn’t there for you. So it’s changed very rapidly. Patient: Everything is brand new. Doctor: Yeah but obviously we should jump on that if we can. Patient: And will they give me the uh BET thing as part of the clinical trial?

text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So often we think of bone as being, we have this sort of feeling that bone is worse, but mostly because we just have trouble imaging and seeing how it changes. So, uh, but it also affects some of the trials we have because those trials require biopsies of tumor tissue, and it’s really hard to get tumor tissue from the bone. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So it may alter what we can do in terms of trials. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So today, I thought we could talk a little bit about kind of what the standard things are to do next, and then we could talk a little bit about some trials that we have. The typical thing we would do next is either to put you on another hormone- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, so you’d be on the shot and a pill. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, we talked before about there’s a drug called, Zytiga, and a drug called, Xtandi. Uh, they both could, could work very well, uh, and they’re both associated with improving survival in men who get the drugs. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: The main side effect of both is fatigue. Patient: Um hum.

Doctor: So it may alter what we can do in terms of trials. Patient: Um hum. The typical thing we would do next is either to put you on another hormone- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, so you’d be on the shot and a pill. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, we talked before about there’s a drug called, Zytiga, and a drug called, Xtandi. Uh, they both could, could work very well, uh, and they’re both associated with improving survival in men who get the drugs. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: The main side effect of both is fatigue. Patient: Um hum.

text: Patient: Worry. You know? Because that, that’s, that’s bad. Doctor: That’s very bad. Patient: Yes. Doctor: Yes. You don’t want to do that. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Stress can cause a lot of problems with the rest, other parts of the body. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Okay? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Wait at the desk and enjoy the rest of the year. I’ll see you in the early part of next year. Okay? Patient: Alright. Alright. Thank you, Dr. P___, so much. Doctor: No problem. Alright. Very good.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
